Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Development of Amphiphilic, pH Responsive Cationic Copolypeptoids for Nonviral Cell Transfection in Serum
Award.AbstractNarration:
Carried out by the process of cell transfection (CT), the practice of gene therapy is a promising approach in addressing rare diseases and genetic disorders (e.g. hemophilia, SCID, and Kippel Trenauny). Among non-viral gene carriers used for CT polymers have received significant attention primarily because their chemical versatility, large-scale production, and cytocompatibility make them potential candidates for biomedical applications. However, drawbacks such as low transfection efficiency and size related cytotoxicity limiting full usage of these systems. In this research, responsive, cationic polypeptoid copolymers will be developed. Under the guidance of Professor Lichen Yin, an expert in cell transfection at Soochow University, synthesized copolymers will be used to investigate the particle stability and behavior of nucleic acid condensed polyplexes during in vitro cell transfection. This research will provide a strategy to stabilize genetic material during cell transfection. This approach will also permit the effective release genetic material intracellularly via endosomal escape.

Poly(N-substituted glycines) are a special class of peptidomimetic polymers bearing substituents on the nitrogen present in the backbone. Commonly referred to as polypeptoids, this group of polymers are known for their minimal cytotoxicity, enhanced proteolytic stability and structural tunability, making them potential candidates for a variety of biomedical and biotechnological applications including smart-coatings, antimicrobial agents, and drug delivery. Currently, the cell transfection of polypeptoid/DNA complexes in serum-containing media is problematic due to the instability of the complexed particles in serum. The manifestation of charge shielding, in which interaction with anionic serum components (lipids, albumin, salts, etc.) reduces polyplex surface charge, is mainly responsible for this outcome. To address this challenge, block polypeptoid copolymers containing hydrophilic and hydrophobic segments will be developed in this project. In this research synthesized copolymers will be tested for their ability to effectively protect and transport therapeutic gene p53 during in vitro cell transfection in nuclease. Under extracellular conditions where charge shielding is permissible (pH= 5.0-5.5), it is anticipated that copolymers will respond to this biological stimuli by adopting a micellar structure with a charged, hydrophobic inner core and charge neutral outer shell. Dr. Yin's group proficiency in the field of cell transfection will contribute significantly towards efforts to understand and elucidate the behavior of these polymeric systems in biological environments.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Synopsis: Gene therapy presents a promising approach towards the treatment of genetic disorders and diseases via the safe and efficient delivery of nucleic acids to damaged cells. In comparison to viral methods, non-viral practices have proven to be more advantageous in sufficient delivery with less immunogenicity and oncogenicity. Synthetic polymers, particularly polypeptoids are elevating in scientific interest as their chemical versatility, large-scale production, and cytocompatibility make them potential candidates for biomedical applications. The goal of this project was to develop and assess responsive, cationic polypeptoid diblock copolymers as carriers for nonviral gene delivery.

Background & Research Objective: To date, cationic homo and random polypeptoids with transfection efficacies surpassing that of high molecular weight polyethylenimine (PEI, a standard gene transfection carrier) in serum-free media have been demonstrated. To acquire a full understanding of their transfection potential, I studied the transfection behavior of polypeptoids under conditions relevant to in vivo environment. Presently, the cell transfection of polypeptoid/DNA complexes in serum-containing media is problematic due to the instability of the complexed particles in serum. The manifestation of charge shielding, in which interaction with anionic serum components (lipids, albumin, salts, etc.) reduces polyplex surface charge, is mainly responsible for this outcome. Because of polyplex instability, genetic material becomes displaced throughout cellular transport resulting in low gene transfection. Ultimately, if gene therapy practices are to be successful in treating and preventing of diseases and disorders significant gene expression is essential for the replacement of defected genes.

Key Findings/Observations: Cationic, diblock peptoid copolymers bearing a pH-responsive linker were successfully developed and fully characterized. Preliminary findings from this project show that the pH-responsive, cationic copolypeptoids are relatively capable of performing gene delivery in conditions prevalent for in vivo environment (in serum). Though successful, transfection efficiencies for the pH-responsive analogues were slightly compromised in serum compared to those obtained in serum-free media. Unlike in the case of serum-free delivery, the pH-responsive copolymers’ performance in serum-containing medium were comparable to that of commercially available PEI. So far, this suggests that issues with the newly designed polypeptoids can overcome obstacles including particle instability and aggregation faced during nonviral gene delivery in nuclease. From CMC measurements, it was revealed that the pH responsive copolymers exhibit micelle character at moderately low concentrations. This further confirmed that diblock analogues were successfully derived. In continuation of this project, additional experiments will be planned and conducted in collaboration with the host institution.

 

2017 EAPSI Experience: Besides providing me with my first out-of-country experience, this EAPSI program has been essential to my overall growth as both a scientist and person. Too often we take for granted the everyday luxuries right in front of us. Spending the past 8 weeks in China reminded me to never do so again, but instead celebrate those riches. This experience has also taught me to give new things a try more often because the adventure that comes with it might just be worth it in the end! I am truly grateful for my host institution, Dr. Lichen Yin, and the Yin research group for welcoming me to their campus and labs this Summer. Many new skillsets and techniques were learned from members of the Yin research group. More rewardingly, lasting relationships and connections were developed.

While in Suzhou I was fortunate to see several of the beautiful wonders the southeastern Jiangsu province has to offer. The city of Suzhou, which is referred to as “city of water and fish” is filled with so with such a fascinating history. I was completely blown away by the treasures and well-preserved artifacts I had the privilege of seeing at the Suzhou museum. As I walked through the botanical trails of The Humble Administrator’s Garden, I instantly felt peace and serenity restored unto me. My captivating visit to Tiger Hill was very enlightening and fun as I was exposed to the city’s great appreciation for ancient nobility.

I also had the chance to visit other cities in China including Shanghai and Beijing while participating in the EAPSI which allowed me to immerse in Chinese culture in different regions. Because of the EAPSI program I now have a greater respect and appreciation for numerous Chinese entities including foods like ‘hotpot’ and deep fried purple yam. Lastly and most importantly, overall this experience has helped me to realize how valuable of a role I play in bridging gaps not only between the native English and Chinese speaker, biologists and chemists, and Master level and doctoral level students, but amongst various departments across the campus of an institution as well. To sum things up, EAPSI has truly taught me that…Communication + Outreach + Smiles = Cooperation and Innovation.

 

 

  

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2018
Modified by: Jessica M Simpson
